description: The garage house is a rental apartment with an indoor garage for car enthusiasts. Unlike regular rental garages where you just store a car, this garage looks beautiful, as if your car is displayed in a showroom, and you can live upstairs.
This brand started in 2014, and currently there are 40 rooms with six properties in the metropolitan Tokyo area. It has become popular with a constant 98% occupancy and a long waiting list.
I was responsible for creating concepts, interior design, and graphic design from the beginning of this project.

blocks.headline: There are no garages for fancy cars in metropolitan Tokyo
description: Since the housing in the metropolitan Tokyo area is smaller than the suburbs, people who own a car cannot have a garage on the premises and have to rent parking space far from home.

Although Japanese car enthusiasts tend to prefer to watch their cars in their spare time and maintain the cars by themselves, they cannot have those experiences at their home. Therefore, we thought there was a market for the garage house that could provide rich experiences for car enthusiasts.

Interestingly, this exact frustration was experienced by the president of Infist Design (who is a car enthusiast himself) when purchasing his car, the Audi R8GT. We were convinced that it was not only him who was feeling the frustration and so we decided to launch the garage house brand for car enthusiasts.

blocks.headline: Market Research / Persona / Concept Planning
description: As our design firm was a small-scale one, I conducted market research, concept planning, and created persona sheets. I then shared all my findings with my team and we reached a consensus on how to proceed with the branding.
Market Research

In Japan, European cars are much more expensive than Japanese cars. For example, even the Audi Q5 is in the category of ultra-luxury cars. I researched the number of popular European cars owned by car enthusiasts in metropolitan Tokyo. As a result, I discovered that

• the number of European cars sold in metropolitan Tokyo was four times more than suburban areas
  • the number of indoor rental garages in metropolitan Tokyo was eight times less than suburban areas

I researched more about the small number of indoor garages in metropolitan Tokyo and most of them looked like a warehouse made from a tin roof and corrugated wall. Clearly, this kind of interior did not match up with luxury European cars, and owners deserved a better design.
Concept Planning
Based on the market research, I defined the principal brand concept:
<q> the garage house which lives with your beloved car</q>

from the idea that there is a garage+house combo where you can live and store your car in style. For car enthusiasts who cherish and take care of their cars like family, I aimed to create a space where

• the car is in a good environment
  • the tenant feels comfortable
  • the tenant wants to show off the garage to friends and family
Persona
I created detailed tenant personas that helped my team members to imagine tenants realistically.
Additionally, since motorcycle enthusiasts in Japan have similar behavior patterns as car enthusiasts, I added them to the collection of personas.

blocks.headline: Presentation to landowners
description: To build a garage house, we need to make a proposition to the landowner that the garage house is attractive as an investment.
Some of the landowners already had made investments in general apartments, and they were looking for a new type of property rental business.
To help with the pitch, I created a brochure that explained to landowners the reasons why the garage house would be the better investment choice compared to general apartments.
Since the type of garage house that can be built varies based on location, environment and budget, support documentation to factor in these variables was included with the brochure.

blocks.headline: Interior design
description: I collaborated with the architect on the design process to help make the final architectural drawing. The layout of the building on the premises revolved around the car and every other part was based on its placement. As the interior designer, I decided on the color scheme and materials for the interior/exterior from many samples. I avoided eccentric colors and materials such as red doors, striped wallpaper, etc., and considered the overall harmony to create a simple and tasteful space.

Because it increases the construction cost, rental apartments in Japan usually avoid using tile as the floor material in the garage. However, the tenant's satisfaction is the key factor in this brand, and so I went with using tile and accenting with a spotlight from the ceiling to make the car appear as if it were displayed in the showroom.

blocks.headline: What I learned from these experiences
description: The landowner's goal is to make high-profit rent income, and for this, the number of units on the lot should be maximized. This approach ends up making each room quite narrow and thus a creative and unique layout is impossible to achieve. Even though a room might have a good interior, this is still not attractive for car enthusiasts who are the focus of this brand.

The first few properties took over six months to reach full occupancy after completion of construction. This happened because the landowner's goal of a high-profit ratio conflicted with the concept to create for the car enthusiasts.

Starting from the third property that set importance to show cars beautifully, 100% occupancy was achieved before completion of construction and remained full all the time with a waiting list for future occupancy. Therefore landowners got rent income from right after completion of construction and they did not need to spend extra money advertising to new tenants. Both contribute greatly to increasing the profit ratio of rent income.

After this discovery, we pivoted the focus of the presentation to better explain to the owner seeking a high-profit ratio of rental income, the importance of showcasing cars and its positive effect on attracting prospective tenants.
Sound Absorber Wall Panels have two primary functions: to absorb unpleasant echo which reflects from walls and to be a beautiful design as a piece of interior.
They are easily installed by even not professional users and customers can choose a design based on the level of sound absorption. As an art director, I did research, product design, print design.

blocks.headline: Problems of sound absorbers and product design goals
description: The opportunity to easily create and distribute one's own music on Youtube, SoundCloud, etc. has increased, and at the same time, devices and applications for recording and editing at home are also easy to buy. However, the majority of sound-absorbing panels that are sold for professional uses look like a big kitchen sponge and are difficult to install for ordinary people; there are no beautiful designs and the ones that exist don't match the home interior.

I decided that creating sound-absorbing panels that are for ordinary people who record at home and at the same time can be considered as part of the interior was a solution for both absorbing sound and interior decorating, in addition to easy self-installation.

blocks.headline: Research and synthesis
description: I tested the sound absorption effect with lots of materials:

• fabric with polyurethane foam
  • wood with polyurethane foam
  • recycled board from plastic water bottles
I discovered differences in the effects when these were located on the walls or ceiling and in the corners of the room.

In these materials, the recycled board from plastic water bottles was easy to manufacture at a factory and most lightweight, as well as easy to install for ordinary users, so we adopted this material for our products.

I showed our prototype to the person in charge of the soundproofing section in numerous musical instrumental stores. They were impressed by the designs and materials; additionally, this type of sound-absorbing panel design was new for them, so I was sure that we were headed in the right direction with our product.

During the research process, we found that not only music-related people need the sound absorption panel, but we also found that there was demand for this kind of product in spaces where people gather and speak, i.e. conference rooms and restaurants.

blocks.headline: Product design
description: Challenging points
For the user, the sound-absorbing panel had to:

• be a beautiful art piece as an interior
  • possess a high sound-absorption effect
  • be easy to mount on the wall
From a manufacturing and cost perspective, it was crucial for the panel:

• to be efficiently sized to manufacture from the panel
  • to be efficiently sized to reduce shipping costs
  • to be at an appropriate price point

Lastly, by expanding the target segment, we discovered that there was a need for the product to be modular because it could be used anywhere from a small living room to a large venue such as a restaurant.

blocks.description: Solutions for design, effective absorption, size

To develop a size that can be used on a surface of any size, I created distinct designs for the panels utilizing a geometric pattern. These designs can adapt to any size of a wall by increasing or decreasing the number of elements in the pattern; they can also be used to express a unique design. Also, a new design was created by adding a variable depth to the panel, which allowed for a difference in the sound absorption effect and made the design more flexible.

Moreover, since the sound absorption effect is enhanced by an air layer, I designed not only flat products but also three-dimensional products with an air pocket so that users can choose depending on the level of sound absorption that they need.

In Japan, plasterboards are mainly used as the interior wall material and are easily pierced by pushpins. When renting, the tenant would be required to pay extra when they leave the apartment if they made holes in the walls. Because of this, I decided to use "insect-pins" for mounting the product to the wall. These make only minimum holes and the user can tap with a hammer to mount instead of drilling the wall.

Additionally, the three-dimension version was designed to have the top panel easily removable in order to mount to the wall with pins.

The material price was rather high, and thus efficiency of material usage was important. By having close communication with the manufacturing factory, we were able to calculate the most efficient size and arrangement when cutting from the source recycled board.

description: Solutions for cost

I was able to avoid wasting material by designing within the optimal size. The products were able to be delivered to users with minimal shipping fees because they were lightweight and stackable.

Another goal was also to reduce costs related to storing already made products. This was accomplished by cooperating with the manufacturing factory and creating a production line that helped minimize stock and only manufacture after receiving orders from customers.

blocks.headline: Verification of the products
blocks.description: I introduced prototypes to editors of various music periodicals, through which we got an opportunity to feature our project in magazines and showcase the testing of absorption effect with sound artists and acoustic professionals. They showed great satisfaction in the result of the absorption effect and described the product as being "perfect for recording at home".

blocks.headline: Conclusion
blocks.description: After the product went on sale at musical instrumental stores and via e-commerce, sales were increasing rapidly. After only a few months on the market, we received numerous requests to install in restaurants and universities. Everything was going great... but unfortunately, due to unforeseen circumstances related to importing materials from Malaysia in 2019, the product was discontinued as soon as the materials stock was exhausted in Japan.

description:
The leaflet created in collaboration with The incell Garage House when the new Audi TT was launched in Japan in 2015. Pictures in the leaflet bring to mind the garage of the Audi TT owner. This leaflet was used as a sales tool for Audi Shinjuku and The incell Garage house.

As an art director, I conducted photo shooting and graphic design.

blocks.headline: Photo shooting direction
blocks.description: I made sheets that show the process of the photoshoot and share them with team members a few days before the shooting. Audi Shinjuku provided three cars to this shooting for different kinds of style of life with the garage. The first sheet shows the concepts of the photoshoot for each car and what kind of equipment we need, the second one is the time table in which team members can check what suppose to do in a certain time in the photoshoot, and the third one shows from which direction we would shoot. Also, I drew the storyboard for every shot.

blocks.headline: Graphic design
blocks.description:
The layout was designed to be a sales tool for both, The garage house and Audi Shinjuku.

As a result, preview audiences to the garage house were increased by Audi's referral and the new garage house reached full occupancy.

description: Reminisce is a hair salon in Saitama, Japan. The owner started and built his own hair salon in his hometown. I created their logo, business card, and tapestry. I used the salon's unique architectural elements as inspiration for my design. I also collaborated with my design team on the hair salon's architecture and construction.

blocks.headline: Logo
blocks.description:
The word "reminisce" is represented by the tea tree in the language of flowers. The owner's parents run a green tea farm and factory, and the hair salon serves a cup of that green tea for each customer.

The concept behind the logo expresses the owner's well-honed creativity and the design of a modern store that stands out in a quiet area surrounded by green tea fields.

blocks.headline: Business card
blocks.description: Business cards play a vital role in a brand's identity in Japan. The card is cut to resemble the architecture of the salon and provides a strong first impression on the person who receives it.

blocks.headline: Tapestry
blocks.description:
Most people get around by car in this area, so the structure has to be recognized as a hair salon from the passing car. I designed the large tapestry that is placed on the outer wall of the salon.

The salon targets primarily female customers and the design focuses on a woman model. The concept is that a person who appears inside a frame is perceived as a painting - a work of art - and hints to potential clients that they will be transformed when visiting the salon.

description: I designed this business card for my friend, Mari Shirai, who works as a location coordinator in the filming industry. She goes to work with her dogs in her yellow Volkswagen van. She is kind of famous because of this to her coworkers and makes a strong impression on new clients. The business card reflects these elements of her style.

blocks.headline: Mark and card
blocks.description:
I sketched the Volkswagen van and her dogs as a hand-drawn illustration with her name in a playful font. This shows her character as friendly and outgoing.

In addition to her name, I added her dog's names in the mark to give a topic for the conversation with the people who exchange the business cards.

description:
Astute is a consulting firm that helps car dealerships to reach out to low-credit customers that they have not been able to acquire. Using their unique knowledge and network, they help car dealers reduce opportunity losses and increase sales.

I redesigned the logo and created a new website for them.

blocks.headline: Logo Renewal
description: The motif of a puzzle piece and green shoots were used in the previous logo to represent their mission of solving problems and leading to new opportunities. I didn't change the motif used in the new logo, but designed it in a modern style.

blocks.headline: Web Design
description: Top Page

I pick a large image of a car as a main visual for being recognized that a car-related business to the main target audience. The Take a Test button which determines how much sales the client is losing is placed on the top page and in the header for easy access.
Services
Expressed what kind of services they provide with illustrations to understand easily.
Client's Problems
By presenting problems that clients often face, it concretely evokes the problem and leads the way to solve them.
Explanation of Steps
I expressed the steps with playful illustrations.
Take a Test

After the client takes a test, the system shows a figure of how much sales they could have gotten if they got low-credit customers. It makes them motivated to solve the problem by showing the exact number.
